primary_factors: HAZARDOUS ROADS: Road condition score 8.0/10 - severely hazardous travel conditions
No meaningful new snow expected Wed morning (closure drivers are residual impacts, not fresh accumulation)
Overnight refreeze/black ice risk from Tue snow/freezing rain, with worst travel window ~05:30–08:30
Road treatment likely adequate on highways/primary arterials by ~06:30, but residential/local streets and some rural connectors may remain variable/slick for bus pickups
Wind chills for 6–8 AM now best-verified around +1°F to +6°F (NOT ≤ -20°F); cold is a discomfort/safety management issue but below automatic-closure threshold
No confirmed neighboring-district closure “domino” signals yet; closings feeds and district sites show no pre-announced Wed closures in accessible scans
Power outages are low in Kent County; statewide outages ticked up but no Rockford/Kent cluster evident
decision_rationale:
Checklist synthesis and weighting (Meteorology 25%, Safety 25%, History 15%, News 15%, Infrastructure 10%, Power 5%, Web verify 5%):

1) Agreement: All experts agree Wed morning is a ‘cleanup/refreeze’ setup with essentially no new accumulating snow during the commute; the main hazard is leftover ice/packed snow from Tue and overnight refreeze, especially on secondary/local roads.

2) Disagreements & resolution: The only potentially high-impact conflict was wind chill. Web verification initially flagged a Weather.com view showing ~-23°F to -24°F, which would strongly push toward closure. Follow-up verification indicates this is likely a page/locale artifact: WeatherAPI + canonical Weather.com + another Weather.com variant cluster around +1°F to +6°F feels-like for 6–8 AM. Therefore, no extreme-cold automatic-closure trigger is supported.

3) Plow timing math: Snow/ice impacts wind down Tue evening, giving ~21 hours to the 6:30 AM bus window. Infrastructure now expects trunklines largely clear and arterials treated by ~06:30, but residential/local streets remain inconsistent. That combination usually supports ‘open’ or a DELAY rather than a full closure.

4) Ice?: Yes—moderate refreeze/black ice risk is the main driver. This pushes probability upward from a pure ‘quiet day’ baseline.

5) Neighboring districts: No confirmed Wed 1/28 closure wave found in the latest accessible scans; this removes a key multiplier that would otherwise add +15–20%.

6) Power outages: Statewide outage count increased (12→187), but Kent County appears near-zero and no Rockford cluster is evident. This is not a closure driver right now.

7) Multi-source wind chill: Best-verified 6–8 AM wind chill is above 0°F and far above the ≤ -20°F threshold.

8) What would make this wrong? If late Tue night observations show widespread glazing/freezing fog on untreated roads (not just isolated spots), or if multiple nearby districts post early-morning closures (domino effect), or if a localized power loss hits key school buildings. Any of those would shift toward a 2-hour delay or, less likely, closure.

Net: With no new snow and no verified extreme wind chill, a full closure remains unlikely, but refreeze + variable neighborhood streets keep it above a ‘routine open’ probability. Final full snow-day (closure) probability: 22%. A 2-hour delay is the more plausible disruption outcome.

collaboration.summary: Agents reached consensus after 2 round(s) with 7.0% spread. Average probability: 18%.
